Comment: I seldom concur with you, and far more often agree with Fr. Reese, but I do think it is overstatement to claim "numerous revolutionary things." For one thing, changes in the "now"--no matter how dramatic-- can't be termed  "revolutionary." To be revolutionary, transforming impact over time must be shown. 

Yes, there can be apparent dramatic change, but whether that change leads to "reform" or "revolution" is yet to be seen. And we must wait to see if future over-reaction and over-correction to today's changes swings the pendulum in an unintended and unpredictable direction.

Comment: This year I had decided I would take my young children (11, 11 and 8 years old) bear baiting for their first big game hunting experience. Hunting bears over bait is the ideal starter hunt for little ones. The action unfolds slowly, you can harvest very selectively and I'm able to  talk them through the experience.

As we approached the bait station on Saturday, I felt as though I had been sucker punched in the gut. My tree stand, game cameras and bait barrel had all been stolen by anti-hunters. (I know they were anti-hunters due to certain details left behind.) The station had been set up to to the very letter of the regulations. I had no words of wisdom to offer my brood of three. They were in shock after all the work we had put in and I was sick that this was their first big game hunting experience.

Disagree with bear baiting? Fine. Testify at a Board of Game meeting. Don't commit hunter harassment and theft. You might also reconsider your self-satisfying sense of moral superiority.

A lot of people don't want equality - they want equity.

Comment: Oh, there's one standard all right. It's that our fundamental rights may only be limited in accordance with the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. And to be in accordance, the limitation must first be logically necessary to achieve a PRESSING AND SUBSTANTIVE need. Second, the limitation must be closely connected to the law's objective, violate the right to a reasonable minimum, and be proportional to the intent of the law. If the law fails any one of those test, it's unconstitutional. 

Quebec's law fails at the first test, and likely would fail at the others too.

Comment: For the first time in... well... pretty much forever, Greece's central government actually had a small surplus in 2016.  Not just a "primary surplus" (ie excluding debt repayments) but an actual surplus.

Unfortunately they still went about 3 billion Euro deeper into debt.  How?  I'm not quite sure, trying to sort out exactly what is happening with government finances is always a difficult exercise but with Greece it is nearly impossible.  I would guess it had something to do with capital expenditures that tend to be counted off-budget (Canadian governments do this as well, particularly at the Provincial level, eg. Ontario is expecting a "balanced" budget while going $10B deeper into debt this year).

Comment: The last time the budget was "balanced" (by the PCs in 2003), it was actually balanced. That is, provincial debt did not go up year-over-year. This budget is not balanced, once all the capital spending that has been shuffled off-budget is included. Debt will increase by $12-13 billion dollars year-over-year. The credit rating agencies are fully aware of these tricks. From Standard and Poor's last credit rating downgrade in 2015: "The stable outlook reflects our expectation that, under our base-case scenario, Ontario will continue to make slow progress in reducing its after-capital deficit in the next two fiscal years..." Note those words: "after-capital deficit." That's what counts. It's still at $12.2 billion, about the average it's been over the years the Liberals have been in power, and higher when one-time "adjustments" and asset sales are taken out.

Comment: Fisheries habitat shift hasn't been a much-studied research topic ever- tho some of it has been casually observed by Alaska fishers here over the past decade or more as the Alaska climate has rapidly warmed. 

Long-recognized over-fishing  on the East Coast may contribute much more than here (so far) to the shift in our catch-based awareness of declines in traditional abundant fisheries grounds, and increased more northerly catches on grounds once regarded as  "marginal" - But there is no doubt that the shift has been happening on both coasts. While I doubt the perceived/actual northerly shift of harvest is solely due to climate change - legal and illegal over-fishing or illegal gear, habitat damage and pollution are all contributors to the perceived habitat shifts - but on the northwest and Alaska coasts that have not as severely damaged their resources, the population shifts & sea-life die-offs over the past couple of decades seem easier to link to our rapid Alaska climate warming.

Comment: In 1934, with the enactment of the Indian Reorganization Act (25 U.S.C.A. § 461, et. seq.), Indian tribes were allowed to exercise their inherent sovereignty to establish their own justice codes and operate court systems enforcing those laws. The Act authorized tribes to organize and adopt constitutions. However, many of the tribally-enacted constitutions were boiler-plate templates, requiring Secretary of the Interior-approval for many tribal government actions. Nevertheless, despite its flaws, the Act is considered a “success” in providing a framework for and first-step towards expanding tribal self-government. www.tribal-institute.org/lists/justice.htm

Comment: I find it interesting professor that your crossroad is about how we treat small business in isolation.  This is a good way to channel the debate, but unfair to taxpayers who bear the burden of all the aspects of tax fairness.

These include: 

1. Excessive compensation for civil servants
2. Excessive benefits for civil servants
3. Pension income splitting by civil servants
4. Stock option plans treated as capital gains for senior managers
5. Trust structures to spread the tax burden among family members and use multiple one time capital gains exemptions
6. Agreements to allow doctors to incorporate to effectively pay an obfuscated higher wage.

To address just the small business issue is disingenuous to say the least.  

But, there was one notion  liked to identify personal corporations that are legit versus just for tax.  Doing so is a no brainier.

So, I suggest we put all this into the hopper and start again.

Comment: "The Russians have framed their new thinking as 'escalate, to de-escalate,' meaning possibly using a small number of nuclear weapons to persuade an opponent not to escalate the conflict and possibly lead to all-out nuclear war."

It's not so much the "small" numbers as the targets they'd aim for.  Any Russian ICBMs headed inbound to US targets would provoke a similar response.  It's unlikely the Russians would target, say, Seattle or Atlanta and leave NY, LA or DC untouched.  And it's unlikely we wouldn't target Moscow, etc. if any of our cities were hit -- no matter which ones.  We wouldn't hold back in our response, because the purpose of a retaliatory strike is as much to prevent a second strike as to punish the aggressor.

Russia could expect a similar outcome if they target any of our NATO allies.  France and the UK are nuclear powers in their own right, but any attack anywhere in Europe would almost certainly guarantee a massive response.  Putin would be mad not to realize this.

Comment: Regarding erasing Robert E. Lee's exploits in particular, that might prove difficult in the officer corps of our own armed forces.  Lee's victory at the Battle of Chancellorsville in April-May 1863 is still regarded as a signature example of dividing a smaller army to successfully engage a much larger enemy force.  Chancellorsville is considered of comparable historical significance in the history of the force of arms to Alexander's victory at Gaugamela.  Twenty-first century Americans might find much to fault with either commander, but there's no way anyone can whitewash military success from textbooks at West Point or VMI.

And speaking of VMI (or the nearby Washington and Lee University), perhaps either school would appreciate the donation of the statue of Robert E. Lee.  I can think of few more appropriate places for it to reside.  (There remains a statue of Thomas "Stonewall" Jackson in New Orleans (in Metairie).  Historical circumstance keeps it unmolested - for now that is.)

I suspect the bounce in price of many of these rate reset preferreds is not because of anticipation that their dividend payments will rise but rather that the dividend cut to come won't be as deep as it might have looked to be just a few short months ago.  
Again at least to me, the far superior investment is one where the dividend rises every year and that dividend paid is not subject to fluctuation (both up and down) based on some unknowable, extraneous factor like the future interest rate on a five-year government of Canada bond. 
Clearly I am looking at this from an inestor's point of view, not as a short-term trader might.
And by the way, sometimes prices rise on dividend-growth companies' stocks in anticipation of their annual dividend increase announcements. It does happen.

Comment: Welcome to the big wide world of adhesion contracts -   a standard form contract drafted by one party (usually a business with stronger bargaining power) and signed by the weaker party (usually a consumer or employee), who must adhere to the contract and therefore does not have the power to negotiate or modify the terms of the contract. Read your airline tickets' common carrier agreements, Apple, Inc. operating software agreements, credit card agreements, bank contracts, etc. etc. .  All are a result of power differentials.  Systemically, we need to get our government back to level the playing field, and have union membership be the rule, not the exception.

The Star Advertiser is throwing its superior bargaining strength around, when it should be innovating to provide new product, changing it's business model, and doing so with the support of its employees.  Instead, it looks like they are just managing their decline on the way to final liquidation, while Sinatra's, "My Way" is played

Comment: I am not sure I see this as a First Nations native problem.

I see this as a Health Canada problem.

Health Canada is responsible for helping Canadians maintain and improve their health and includes affiliated statisticians and public health experts. It is in part a DETECTION entity, it NOTICES bad trends out in Canada where more people die from "X" or "Y" than elsewhere in Canada.

Look, if Health Canada is not empowered to throw expert resources at localized problems once it uncovers them, then we might as well disband Health Canada and end it.

It does not matter if the problem is asbestos in a Quebec town or ground radium in a Prairie town, once a problem is statistically verified by Health Canada, a federal agency, there needs to be a "treatment" arm to provide the needed intervention.

I do not see this as a native problem. I think all Canadians simply need to decide if they want to have an effective Health Canada or not.

Comment: Fifty-six countries retain capital punishment. Capital punishment is a legal penalty in the United States and is currently used by 31 states. The state governor is the one who authorizes the execution warrant, and the only one who can grant pardon. It should therefore rightfully be the governor who initiates the fatal dosages, or switches the power on for electrocutions, or releases the gas into the chamber, or activates the gallows platform, or pulls the trigger.

Justifying or tolerating capital punishment is nigh on justifying or ignoring the crucifixion. Everyone's hands are bloodied and, like Pilate, the responsibility for the reality cannot be simply rinsed away.

Comment: Using Sea Ice Extent as a metric is literally just looking at the surface of the situation. Antarctic Sea Ice Volume has been declining at 1% a year for decades. That is slower than the 3% annual decline in the Arctic, but it still translates into enough lost ice to cover millions of sq km of ocean if it were spread 1 meter thick. In the Arctic the 20 meter multi year pressure ridges that forced the MV Manhattan to give up on the McClure Parry passage in 1968 and 1969 are gone, replaced by thin single seasonal ice that melts away during the summer, just as Seasonal Antarctic Ice melts away in December and January.

Comment: Some portions of a Telegraph report from April are interesting:

"The (Italian) government says it has little choice but to rescue the migrants, but critics say that trafficking gangs in Libya have come to depend on Italian, EU and NGO vessels deployed in the Mediterranean as a free taxi service.

Comment: That system has great shortcomings from the victim side as well, in my opinion. When a complainant feels that the offence is too minor to bother with, it's the "bother" part that we have to be most concerned about. Maybe the incident wasn't as minor as the complainant thinks, as in she could be conditioned to think of sexual assault as normal. Then again, maybe the perpetrator was a repeat offender. Maybe it was a minor offence, but a prelude to worse assaults against someone else. Those are troubling possibilities, because a problem that could be dealt with early on might persist or grow worse.

The "bother" the complainant is concerned about is, ultimately, a criminal trial where she will be the primary witness. That's a very heavy burden to take on. Again I point out that perhaps some other means of dealing with the complaint outside of the criminal justice system might make women more willing to come forward.

Comment: Interestingly income taxes aren't even all that much higher in Scandinavian countries, particularly for high income earners.  The top tax rate in Sweden is 56% vs. 53% in Ontario (slightly higher or lower for other Provinces).  That top rate kicks in at much lower income levels in Sweden though, and taxes on lower income earners are quite a bit higher, eg. the bottom bracket is 30% vs. 20% in Ontario.

Ohh, and corporate taxes are lower in Sweden, at 22.0% vs. 26.5% in Ontario (again other Provinces are similar).

The only area where taxes are MUCH higher in Sweden is their VAT.  At 25% for most goods and 8% for "essentials" like food from grocery stores it is much higher than the 13% (0% for "essentials") in Ontario.

Comment: "The whole unseemly affair tainted the crucial first days of Mr. Scheer’s leadership. Was the Conservative Party coming apart after a divisive and, it now it appears, flawed leadership vote?"
***
I know that CPC supporters are happy to see this end. It only goes to show what a problem ranked balloting would have been had this become the way to conduct federal votes in this country. In this case, it was a decision of who would become leader. In a national vote, it would have resulted in a combination of which Parties would form governance and what compromises would have resulted in securing governance. Canadians would have voted for a Party and their policies, and their Party may have won the popular vote, and yet they might not govern. Elections are not supposed to be a poker game. Democracy and sound economy requires political stability and consistency.
Scheer's leadership was not tainted as he did not interfere with the outcome of the vote or voting process.

Comment: VII was supposed to empower the laity but Canon Law still leaves us overly dependent on the cooperation of clerics.  Lay trusteeism is still not allowed.  Even for things that are the rights of the laity, there is no option but parish-hopping in practice.  Those seeking for their own good Masses where the instructions in Sacrosanctam concilium and Musicam sacram are actually followed, etc. for example need only drive but at the same time don't get personal parishes.

Only the Extraordinary Form is protected, and then not by the CJC but by the Ecclesia Dei commission and the acts of two good popes.  Those protections are strong for good historical reason, and they are working.  In some respects the establishment of an Ordinariate for those of Anglican heritage was similarly motivated; per Bishop Lopes's history of the problem, diocesan officials repeatedly sabotaged previous efforts.  Would that these two successful models were extended to protect and empower the laity more generally!

Comment: Excuse me, but most parents already pay taxes to support the DOE.  They have already paid plenty to the schools.  It's what schools--and some teachers--do with those resources that are often the problem.  There are needs, and there are wish lists.  There are must-have supplies and wouldn't-it-be-nice-supplies.  There are ways to recycle and wisely use items, and there are ways to waste items.  Another example is textbook purchasing.  In my experience, some teachers/departments took care of their textbooks, required students to protect them with paper covers, kept an inventory, and held students accountable for lost or damaged-beyond-repair books.  Others took little care of the $50 per copy books because, when they were lost, textbooks were considered a necessity and one could always get money to replace them or even buy brand new sets.  As for supplies, buying in bulk for a department or grade level from Fisher Hawaii or other suppliers does not create a HIDOE bureaucracy.

Comment: Most Canadians believe that we have property rights in this Country - we don't.
Here is some advice to potential BC landlords that I have learned the hard way.  There are some good and responsible tenants who will respect your property and they should be protected from rapacious landlords, sadly there are some tenants who won't and who are pro's at gaming the BC Residential Tenancy Act to their advantage:  1) Assume you will be ripped off and plan accordingly:  2) if you don't want to do the homework yourself - hire a professional agent:  3) have your tenancy agreement written up by a lawyer who knows the Act:  4) Always do a fixed term tenancy that does not go month-to-month after the term is over and specify the renewal terms: 5) run credit checks:  6) talk to previsous landlords not just references:  7) if the address for service provided by the tenant is not the rental unit, send a registered letter to that address in advance:  8) Ask to see photo ID: and 9) do employment checks.

Comment: I once saw the invoice for a "routine mobile service" whereby the friendly mechanics from Mercedes Benz show up at your door to perform an oil change and basic inspection.  If I recall, the invoice for not even two hours of work was $800, paid for by wireless Point-of-Sale machine.   A Honda might only take 5L of oil, but a 5-6L V8 motor with a large sump might take 12L of oil at $20+/Litre of factory-labelled synthetic oil.  Including the filter, you might be looking at $300 just for the parts!

The biggest reason for delaying oil changes that are unnecessary, are simply environmental.  Think of all the oil that our vehicles use for lubrication.  If we are all changing the oil at a proper interval, think of the huge quantity of oil that wouldn't be required.  

Do you throw out your shoes and tires with 50% tread remaining "just to be on the safe side?"  Why is oil any different?

Comment: Errr....

1. Employees also save on their own beyond the PERA mandated 8%.

2. The State -- as an employer -- would have to contribute to Social Security if CO participated, so the real "voluntary" contribution is half the figure you cite. 

3. Like many private employers, the State would (alternately) be contributing towards 401k's (in many cases, as mandated by law).

Bottom Line: this is a pension system. There's no "wow" in this formula. Government isn't subsidizing private employers who dump their retirement burdens off on taxpayers a few decades in the future - here, the burden is demanded up-front, preemptively so future taxpayers aren't burdened. Unfortunately, Colorado wants to do the worst of both: commit to a conservative approach by funding this liability in advance but also not funding it so taxpayers in 2030, or 2040, or 2050 have to make up the difference. If some alternative appears cheaper to you that's because costs are being shifted or ignored.

Comment: At Oslo (1993) the PLO renounced violence and unambiguously accepted Israel's right to exist. But while Oslo provided Palestinians with symbols of independence like the right to issue stamps and raise flags, the settlements were expanded, the occupation further entrenched and Palestinians nationally humiliated with Arafat reduced to a virtual Israel prisoner. (Hence the adamant refusal of Hamas to follow suit.)

The late academic Edward Said (who was instrumental in convincing the PLO to abandon its dream of a secular state in all of Palestine and accept a two-state solution) vociferously denounced the Oslo Accords as a "capitulation" and refused the White House invitation to attend the "historic" Arafat-Rabin handshake. He warned that the PLO would be reduced to a Vichy-type government (a Palestinian Authority with no authority) whose role would be to effectively police Israel's occupation.

Edward Said's fears have been vividly validated.

Comment: Not to be too anal, but you mean VPSO (Village Public Safety Officer), not VSPO. And I believe Wassillie, the victim, was a VPO (Village Police Officer), not a VPSO. There is a big difference. A VPSO goes through state training & is recognized & supervised & paid by the state. There are way more VPOs than VPSOs. VPOs get a lot less training, & none of it is from the state that I know of. VPOs get lower pay, & VPOs are not officially recognized by the state due to the state's  opposition to tribal sovereignty. VPOs are paid & supervised by tribal councils. VPOs have high turnover & are often very young guys. VPSOs are meant to be a career option & have longer term professionals, generally. Both jobs are very tough & involve putting yourself in danger without a gun. High stress & low pay. Lots of alcohol-fueled domestic disputes, sometimes relatives. 

And to #3, yes the booze came from Bethel, the only hub here. The villages all vote to be dry but BET lets it pour in & profits from it.

Comment: Outsider77: As I understand  the "issue":

If you have an uncommon name, you're usually through in seconds after the app is typed and submitted. Let's put that scenario aside.

The delay goes to those people, usually with a relatively common name, that pops up a bunch of offenders. You don't get the automatic approval and now a human has to start digging. No big so far, expected. Unfortunately, you lived in another state previously, too. So a request is put out to that state to validate you're the one and same person. The PD that has the record see's an offense but it's not listed as a misdemeanor or felony version, they need to go look it up. It's not a priority for them. This is just another scenario.

All that being said, the firearm seller then has the final call once that delay is up. Three days pass, 10 days pass; they are now in the decision seat.

Will 7 extra days help or hinder? Who knows. IMO, this should wait for full session, not abbreviated "fix" session. It needs input.

Comment: By no means am I a lawyer, but I nevertheless have questions regarding this. In response to deficient resources and court delays, it seems that various court systems throughout Canada are adapting an "appraisal" approach to justice. While this may be applicable to civil court,  and indeed one could argue that this is done with reference to cases subject to arbitration following discovery, how does it suffice for criminal cases? Frankly, I though archivists and realtors concerned themselves with "appraisal" more than lawyers and judges.

Needless to add, if various provinces choose to adapt an "appraisal" approach to criminal justice,  what value criteria will be employed in aid of this approach? Having worked in archives, the problem of value criteria vexes archivists to this day. The difference between determining the value of archival documents and criminal cases is profoundly different in my estimation.

Comment: In 2002 when the newspapers were printing similar stories about Cpl Furlong's shot in Afghanistan, I was having lunch with a recently retired member of Canada's armed forces (Cpt, RCAF). When I mentioned the shot, he had the same opinion as some of the people here about the news coverage -- it was distasteful and disturbing.

I was young at the time, and hadn't thought about it that way, but quickly decided I agreed with him. One can acknowledge the necessity of killing in war without treating it like a sport. When we talk about the record for longest kill shot similarly to how we talk about the record for fastest 100m sprint, it says something about what we think of human life.

Comment: As someone who attended early meetings regarding this project, the neighborhood objections are much more than parking. Like "save the salmon" the late buses are the legal device used to try to get developers to step up their game for cheap, shortsighted profit gains. For a project that will loom over an older neighborhood it's presentation to concerned neighbors appeared less than honest. It's a lost opportunity for a design "win" for the arterial retail street that will take away amenities that already exist. 
Would it be so terrible to dig down? What is parking for the next few hopefully short years could be warehouses for retail on the block, resident storage space, or a winter farmer's market space in the next decade when there is less car dependence. In other words a different profit center than residential rent. In a building with more than 50 micro units at one point (still?) there was space for 5 bikes and no laundry facilities. How Is this good design for newcomers or nimbys?

Comment: "I don't see why companies should pay an income tax at all since their employees pay income tax on behalf of the company anyways"

That sounds like you're suggesting there's a "double taxation" on that part of a company's income that is paid to employees. If you're not suggesting this, disregard the following...

Employees pay income tax on their salaries and wages, less any allowed pre-tax deductions.

In general, companies don't pay income tax on amounts paid to (or on behalf of) employees. That includes salaries and wages, the employer's share of SS/Medicare taxes, an employer's contribution to health care plan premiums, etc.

Comment: Mr. Stockland gravely misstates the case, and in doing so is liable to create more anti-religious sentiment.

Freedom of religion does not entitle anyone to build a church, cemetery or shrine wherever they wish. For that matter, neither do the freedoms of conscience, thought, belief, expression or association give anyone that right. None of our most fundamental Canadian freedoms grant one an unrestricted right to do what one wishes on a piece of land.

Freedom of religion means that federal and provincial governments will not discriminate against you in any way regardless of your beliefs. But when it comes to ACTING on your beliefs, that's another matter. Your actions must conform to all manner of laws and regulations, regardless of what your religious beliefs may be. This is also true of everyone be they a believer or not.

Saint-Apollinaire was a zoning bylaw matter. It wasn't an attack on a religion and it certainly wasn't an attack on Canada's fundamental rights.

Comment: Nope.  Just applying the law as written by Parliament.

The RCMP are arresting and detaining them under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and turning them over to Canada Immigration for processing.

There is a very good legal reason why refugee claimants (not asylum seekers which are a completely different class of persons) are not being charged in respect of their entry to Canada.

Under Article 31 of the 1951 Convention on Refugees Canada has undertaken to not prosecute refugee claimants for illegal entry into Canada including any issues of false documents or fraud relating to that entry.

Canada has enacted that exemption into our domestic law as required by the Convention in various iterations of our immigration legislation over the years. Currently that exemption is contained at s. 133 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.

So no charges because the law exempts refugees recognizing that refugees who are fleeing persecution are different from other migrants.

Comment: Corn ethanol is a value added product of feed production which uses a waste stream from it called the carbohydrates which normally are wasted onto the ground undigested in livestock manure.  It leaves the feed(i.e. the proteins, fats, and minerals) alone, actually enhanced to be healthier, more digestible, and more productive. 

As such we will grow the same amount of corn acres with or without ethanol.  No destruction of farmland.  

Corn ethanol does not even show up as a blip on this corn chart over time:

https://uploads.disquscdn.com/images/91d7502e043c7c976bdbac4d3953fb82813e0ab4ef4723a5d70e734514dcac9c.jpg

In fact, we had more acres of corn in the the 1920s, 1930s, and 1940s than we do today with 1932 the greatest at >113 million acres.  Compare that to 2015, the year corn ethanol mandate maxed out, at 88 million acres of corn.

https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/results/08C6BF8A-850C-3EDB-A929-C39BD2395217

Comment: In the early 1980's, The Southern Baptist Convention (SBC) did approve a non-binding resolution not to ordain women. This resolution and other resolutions from SBC  State Conventions, and other bodies are solely advisory in nature. 
In Baptist Tradition, the congregation is autonomous and decide by themselves the course of action how they should go forward.  The congregation decides on all aspects of policy and there isn't a higher body like the diocese or an authority like the Pope to get them to toe the line.  This is where you have read the resolution wrong looking from a lense of a top-down organization.
There have been SBC Congregations that have called women as pastors and teachers.  The congregation decides also when to dismiss the pastor and make for a call for another. And the SBC National Office has no say in determining the local congregation selection as pastor.

Comment: My comment above is meant to express that the conventional definition of the sacred, "set apart," is not that helpful to me.  I find the conventionally sacred-the sacraments, the Scriptures, the Mass-beautiful and helpful, but see the rest of the world as also infused with the Holy, the presence of God, which is my experiential understanding of "sacred."

-I see the Majesty of God in the Mass, but just as much in the Redwood National Forest, or the ordinary trees and birds in my backyard.
-I see goodness in the life-long religious people at my parish, but also in the courage and faith of my psychiatric patients who have no idea what religion means to them yet endure suffering gracefully.
-At a critical turning point in my life it was the words of Dostoyevsky-not Scripture or the Catechism-that shook me out of a blind selfishness I needed to die to.

 I believe the whole world is a gift from God, so I have no desire or reason to set things apart.

Comment: As an employer for more than 20 years in the tech sector, here’s my perspective on employee premium payments:

The only functional difference between the employer paying $100 toward health insurance, versus putting $100 in the paycheck and having the employee pay that $100, is that in the first case the dollars are tax-deductible for the employer, while in the second case the dollars are taxable income for the employee.

For the employer to pay the premiums just makes sense.

Comment: This story misses the mark. The CBA pilot projects and their results actually tell a powerful story of shared accountability and great success on equity outcomes (www.portlandcbapilotprojects.com).  Any implication of wrong doing by CBA partners is false. The CBA oversight committee proactively developed CBA fund strategies, City staff served on the CBA oversight committee and RFP review committees, RFPs were publicly disseminated to solicit proposals, and CBA partners who submitted proposals did not serve on related RFP review committees nor vote on funding decisions.  The real questions: Why did the City provide so little guidance to partners regarding CBA funds? If the City had concerns, why did City staff fail to raise these concerns over three years as part of the CBA oversight committee?  Why are City staff now choosing to focus on unsubstantiated "perceived" conflicts as opposed to actual CBA project outcomes and activities?

Comment: @Wolf Eagle:  Quite a rant.  Let me offer a different perspective.  I once served on a jury that involved charges of assault and attempted murder.  The prosecutor easily proved the assault charge; we were unanimous in our first vote.  However, the attempted murder charge just wasn't supported. He made the mistake Juror 4 refers to:  he inferred that the actions were so severe that anyone would interpret them as attempted murder, but introduced no evidence that the defendant took any action that could be interpreted as attempting murder.  In deliberation, some jury members considered the inference sufficient. Others, however, pointed out that it hadn't been proven, and the jury hung  on that charge.

I don't know the details of how the prosecution handled this case, and I don't know the motivation of Juror 4.  But I have firsthand experience in a similar situation, and it's not hard for me to image that he could be accurately portraying the situation.

Comment: Tita Girl:

Congressional compensation before the ACA consisted of a salary plus federal healthcare. If they switched to the ACA and were required to pay 100% of the new premiums, that would have meant a substantial reduction in their gross compensation. The subsidy they receive is equivalent to the cost to the government of the federal healthcare that previously had been provided to them. The effect of the subsidy is that their gross compensation is equal to what it was before the switch to the ACA. 

As a business owner or board member, I have had several instances where an employee had reason to request that they be allowed to opt out of the company-provided healthcare in order to purchase their own healthcare. We agreed and paid them what the cost of their coverage had been to the company. That was fair. Their compensation remained the same and there was no additional cost to the company. The Congressional switch from federal employee coverage to the ACA worked the same way.

Comment: The decision not to raise the flamingo pole is a good one. As a non-native artist who has worked with northwest coast native, master carvers, I know firsthand something of the thorny issues involved in practicing in this artistic tradition. To the peoples of the coast whose identity is reflected by story poles, these artistic idioms are sacred. In trying to explain to fellow non-natives just why this flamingo pole was so offensive and painful, I might compare it to flag burning or perhaps some public desecration of the Bible. I might also compare the issues of cultural appropriation to a copyright dispute. Sometimes, artistic expression, even when well-intentioned, can cause real injury. I can empathize very well with the pain and frustration of the flamingo carvers since, as an artist, I live with all kinds of limitations in regard to what I can do in the northwest coast artistic idiom. However, the pain the raising of this pole would cause far outweighs any benefits to its creators.

Comment: Congratulations: when you say that it's not the case that "all white people are racist" you've simultaneously mischaracterized the test (people of color find themselves biased against people of color) and defeated a straw man.

But you show them a test that says that they are members of a society that prizes one kind of person over another, and they become very analytic  about the procedures and very real limits of this kind of testing.

"Wildrose Leader Brian Jean says he’s not confident members of his party are ready to support a unification deal with the Progressive Conservatives, as some MLAs warn of concerns within party ranks.

Jean and PC Leader Jason Kenney announced Thursday a tentative agreement to join together in a new “United Conservative Party.”

To go forward, the deal needs to be ratified by members of both parties, with the Tories setting a threshold of 50 per cent plus one for approval. Wildrose, however, requires 75 per cent support from its members at a special meeting for the UCP to go ahead.

“I’m not confident of that and that’s why I’m out making sure,” said Jean, when asked whether the deal has three-quarters support among Wildrose members.

Comment: The RCMP are arresting and detaining them under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and turning them over to Canada Immigration for processing.

There is a very good legal reason why refugee claimants (not asylum seekers which are a completely different class of persons) are not being charged in respect of their entry to Canada.

Under Article 31 of the 1951 Convention on Refugees Canada has undertaken to not prosecute refugee claimants for illegal entry into Canada including any issues of false documents or fraud relating to that entry.

Canada has enacted that exemption into our domestic law as required by the Convention in various iterations of our immigration legislation over the years. Currently that exemption is contained at s. 133 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.

So no charges because the law exempts refugees recognizing that refugees who are fleeing persecution are different from other migrants.

Comment: Many Asian women did indeed provide “comfort” services to the Japanese Imperial Forces during World War II, but I do not believe they did it at the point of a gun nor was it sexual slavery.    Throughout history, military forces have had no problem finding “comfort women” regardless of the country in which they operated and they were able to find them without kidnapping, coercion or threats of any kind.  Wars create horrible conditions which cause people to resort to often unthinkable means to survive.  For many women, it was the use of their bodies, and there usually was more supply than demand.  I personally witness this during the Korean War and during two years in Vietnam.  Some members of the Imperial Japanese forces no doubt forced women to have sex, which, of course, is rape, but I believe the “comfort women” who served the Imperial Japanese forces in brothels that sprung up and operated near Japanese bases did so voluntarily for pay.

Comment: I disagree.  BC brought in a revenue-neutral carbon tax years ago, and has the strongest economy nationally.  The money earned from the carbon tax was paid back as reduced income taxes, which helps stimulate the economy.  A carbon tax is simply a mechanism to try to reduce unthinking polluting behaviour, and a revenue-neutral carbon tax redirects the costs for polluting back to the consumer.  The rebate could be provided in various ways, including as a direct income tax rate reduction, or, as monies directed toward useful and beneficial infrastructure, which may further aid our society in reducing harmful emissions and improving health and wellbeing.

It's a very knee-jerk and ill-informed reaction to ignore climate science and despise all action.  All of our homes and families face increasing risks and costs from inaction.  I support the federal government's action, and hope that more follows.

Comment: To regress back to the primary subject of Brett's report, there are several web sites that offer much of the graphical and predictive information that a Hawaii resident or visitor needs to plan for the impending storm.  The most comprehensive is the Central Pacific Hurricane Center: http://www.prh.noaa.gov/cphc/  This site also has links to the Eastern Pacific outlook that gives graphic information about tropical storms  brewing off the West Coast of Central America before they cross into CPHC territory.  The Radar and Satellite images available from the Hawaii NWS site: http://www.prh.noaa.gov/hnl/pages/AFD.php are also invaluable.  The only caveat is that of late, NOAA seems to be having difficulty updating the Hawaii radar site on a timely basis and better information may be available from the University of Hawaii Meteorology site: http://weather.hawaii.edu/  Hawaii residents should familiarize themselves with these sites and learn how to use them

Comment: Berman writes that a “measure of inflation that excludes volatile food and energy items declined to 1.5 per cent in April, which is below the Fed’s 2-per-cent target, and the latest ISM non-manufacturing survey suggests it could fall further.” That would be the PCEPILFE, the personal consumption expenditure price index excluding food and energy, which went from an annual inflation rate of 1.6% in March to 1.5% in April. However, while this is the preferred core inflation measure of the US Fed, its inflation target indicator is actually the PCEPI itself, which had a 1.7% inflation rate in April, down from 1.85% in March. Also, the US Fed also looks at another core inflation measure, the trimmed mean, whose 12-month rate of change was 1.75% in April, down from 1.8% in March.

Comment: ...
Part of the problem has been in how regulations were formed for highway standards & who championed those changes; those which allowed for thin layers of asphalt tar + dusts of gravel, over simple gravel base that settles.

The roadways in Alaska that were build prior to and just after the 1964 Earthquake, were thick and laid-down by heavy equipment, also had underlayment of gradient rocks from heavy to lighter, with more solid base. This has an effect of being stable over most climate seasonal shifts in temperature, humidity, and freeze-thaw repetitions.

When those old road layers were being broken up + hauled away (some used along rivers & ocean bays, as breakwater fill) replacement materials were increasingly thin; without suitable base layers, & the rule behind how roads were constructed had been changed. If by profit (or to keep cost-per-mile lower) they've succeeded by making a standard much less than 1950s & '60s. New roads: built thin, over many feet of one-grade of gravel.

Comment: Chaos? Oh please. A few cases across the entire country have been terminated under the Jordan rules. Meanwhile the very foundation of our justice system- the Charter of Rights and Freedoms- has had it's legal provisions upheld. 

"11. Any person charged with an offence has the right...
    (b) to be tried within a reasonable time;...
    (d) to be presumed innocent until proven guilty according to law in a fair and public hearing by an independent and impartial tribunal..."

In the pursuit of justice, society has taken the extraordinary step of presuming innocence in anyone charged with a crime. The onus is on everyone in the justice system, including defence lawyers, to complete trials expeditiously. To do otherwise directly violates the right to be tried within a reasonable time, and makes a mockery of the right to presumption of innocence.

It's not the Charter that must bend to the justice system. It's the justice system that must comply with the Charter. Get on with it, please.

Comment: Our experience of Jesus is one of the masculine gender who revealed God as "Father."  Yes, God, in fact, possesses no gender, per se, but it is through the medium of gender identification that He did choose to reveal Himself.
I suggest that it is, rather, the re-imagining of God in our own image (versus that which He revealed) that imposes limits beyond those that our limited capacity for understanding already impose.  The terms of "Lord, Master, Almighty Father, King, the Holy One", as you point out, are not exclusive of others... but they are not incorrect, either.  Jesus may be simultaneously king an shepherd, The First Person may be at once Father and, analogously, a bird (Ps 91:4).  
"What message is being conveyed by our predominant use of titles portraying power and dominance for God?"
I answer that God, Who created us for no other reason than love, is due our worship, regardless of how He chose to reveal Himself, disagreeing theologians notwithstanding.

Comment: I don't think there should be public sector unions.  Gov't workers already have vast protections, in law and regulation, regarding health benefits, hiring, firing, and pay.  For me, private company unions, however, are a different story.  Workers who are also subject to the variances in the economy, and a corporation, should be able to bargain the same way that a CEO can bargain with the board for compensation.  Overall, since the 1930s, private sector unions have had a positive effect on pay, worker safety, working conditions for the American middle class.  And please don't comment that the unions have forced jobs overseas unless you do some research.  I'm always open to facts on this subject and am willing to change my mind. Signed: not-a-dem-or-repub-on-this-issue.

Comment: There are many alternatives to opioid medication for most who suffer from chronic or acute pain. Except during and immediately after surgery, burn patients and last stage hospice patients, few people have pain that cannot be managed in some other way. If opioid maintenance is someone's only option it is almost always because, being the only option a physician has knowledge of, it is the only option made available to the patient. Neurostimulators to anti-depressants, Acupuncture, over the counter medications and many more effective long and short-term pain management options should be the first treatment plan physicians turn to when helping patients handle pain. Patients also need to understand some pain is normal and the difference between acute and chronic pain. I would be interested in what alternative pain management training the medical center is giving to the physicians on staff who routinely prescribe opioids for pain.

Comment: Dear Fr. Claw (as I have seen reference to your priestly vocation, but have not personally seen you confirm it):  I would like to commend you on both your wit and your candor. A church with such a sordid past naturally tries the very soul of the earnest seeker.  Like many of us, I suspect there was a point in time when the revelation of Rome's many misdeeds and imperial doctrine really hit home with you. Your ability to "confess" the shortcomings of Rome's imperial-styled doctrine is nothing short of refreshing. And the "wit" you add to this puts things in perspective and--for me at least--helps to heal some of the pain. 

"We evolve," as you suggest, lest we go completely insane trying to fit square, antiquated pegs into round, modern holes. Evolution will be slow but the fact that change is underfoot provides comfort for some... far too slow for others, unfortunately. Meanwhile, might I suggest your authoring a book in the spirit of healing, openness and historical truth telling?

Comment: Loren and William,

While the two of you are focused on Doss being a non-combatant, I was attempting to enlarge our view and illustrate the practical challenge of our church needing to become known for ministering God's love by doing many good works that improve lives and draw the attention of people to Him. It is good now and then to look back and celebrate our heroes. Then we must face forward again and get back to making what we do with our hands to minister God's love more powerfully than our words so the people we touch will glorify God.

A few nights ago my son reminded me of the message he remembered from Doss: that God calls each of us to faithful service for Him and that we need to be faithful in doing what He calls us to do so others will be in the Kingdom. So I remember Desmond Doss as far more than a non-combatant because he spent his life inspiring others to faithful service for God in a variety of ways.

A group of parents can have a weekly crock pot dinner night. One parent makes a crock pot meal and the other bring bread, crackers, fruit, juice or help with paper plated.
Another community idea is for a group, Eagles, Elks, VFW, American Legion, to each take a turn in sponsoring a Saturday breakfast or a Friday night cook out.
Grandparents or single bored people that like cooking can offer free cooking classes for kids and their adult.
Kids do not have Home Economics any more as a required class.

Comment: Rich Mole: Elitist political parties have in general tried over the past several generations to keep a lid on contentious issues. Some see this kind of behavior as tempering while others view it as undemocratic. Trump didn't observe the custom, much to the chagrin of many in his own party. In Canada, of course, our mainstream parties have essentially kept a lid on the immigration debate for two or more decades and no government has ever sought sought or obtained 'social licence' for the mass immigration program. Will immigration become a political issue in the future? That's a good question. It would only take a political maverick to bring the issue to the fore. History illustrates that democracy, like nature, abhors a vacuum. It will be interesting to see how long our illustrious mainstream politicians can defy gravity on this.

Comment: Peeing in the park/alley when you think no one is looking is not an offense that requires registration as a sex offender in the State of Colorado. It does not meet the elements of Indecent Exposure, which requires a KNOWING exposure of genitals to the view of another person when done with the intent to arouse. It also does not meet the elements of Public Indecency (which only requires registration after a second conviction within 5 years), which requires a KNOWING exposure of genitals to the view of another person.

Also, the juvenile sex offender registry is not made available to the public in the same way as the adult sex offender registry. And first-time juvenile sex offenders are able to petition for de-registration once they have successfully completed their sentence.

Comment: If the legislature was a jury, the judge would have declared a mistrial long ago and we'd start over with fresh jurors.  The inability and unwillingness to budge an inch from party platforms and what "constituents" seem to want has led to a declared impasse.

Gov. Walker offers a compromise.  Like it or not, at least he sees compromise as a way through the ideological impasse.  This country is built on compromise.  (Check the history books.)

Spread the pain, legislators.  Don't target the pain medicine; administer it to the entire state and we can feel the pain together.  Put a "sunset" clause into legislation that gets us through the current crisis and people may see that taxes/dividend cuts are not cast in stone.

Compromise by using the calendar wisely: for instance, a summer-only sales tax will draw in more cash from tourist trade. Consolidate 53 school districts into one.  If Hawaii can do it, why can't we?  Raise the gasoline tax.  Create a luxury tax (exempting basic foods).
